desc.size: Shrub or small tree, 2.5 - 7 m tall, 2 - 4 m wide. Upright, leggy, with an irregular shape.

part.partText: stout, angled, appearing 4-sided during first year, lustrous brown, smooth, with small raised lenticels. Leaf scars raised, crescent-shaped. Pith solid, white.
reddish brown, 1.5 - 3 mm long, egg-shaped. Terminal buds in pairs, reddish brown, 6 - 8 mm long, egg-shaped, plump, somewhat 4-sided, with overlapping scales.

opposite, stalked, dark green to almost bluish green, 5 - 12 cm long, to as wide, egg-shaped or broadly egg-shaped, base flat or heart-shaped to broadly tapering, tip pointed, margins non-toothed, smooth.
have both male and female reproductive organs (perfect); borne in a 10 - 20 cm long, branched inflorescence; lilac, about 1 cm long, tubular, 4-lobed, very fragrant.
a smooth, beaked, 2-chambered capsule that splits open and releases seed, 1 - 1.5 cm long.

similarSpecies.comments: Syringa vulgaris reaches a height of 7 meters, while S. velutina will only grow to about 3 meters. Also, S. vulgaris has smooth leaves, unlike S. velutina, whose leaves are densely hairy underneath (usually).

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Often planted as an ornamental. Many of the mapped records are based on plants that have persisted after homesite abandonment. A few plants were found growing in sandy soils near Lake Michigan. In general, Syringa species thrive best in moist soils.

notes.comments: Introduced from Europe. There are about 800 different cultivars known to come from Syringa vulgaris.

etymology.comments: Syringa means lilac. It derives from the Greek word syrinx (pipe), and refers to the hollow stems. Vulgaris means common.
